description: From Latin monodia, from Ancient Greek μονῳδία (monōidía).

entries.meaning: An ode, as in Greek drama, for a single voice, often specifically a mournful song or dirge. [from 17th c.]
Any poem mourning the death of someone; an elegy. [from 17th c.]
A monotonous or mournful noise. [from 19th c.]
examples: Stroke by stroke, the great familiar monody of that incomparable curfew rose and fell in the stillness.

entries.meaning: (music) A composition having a single melodic line. [from 19th c.]
